review_title: Good vision but no plan to get there
pros: Competitive starting pay. Good (but not fantastic) benefits. Strong intent from senior leaders (new to the company in the last ~2 years) to make it an ethical and ethically-run company. Requirement for formal performance feedback every 6 months. Slowly moving away from multiple antiquated computer systems and duplicate processes across the company (it takes time).
cons:
I've worked for Wells Fargo for 2 years and have decades in the work world, and it is an odd environment. There are still so many silos, even within the same small organization, and every manager feels empowered to do what they want or they feel is best, and there is no culture here that people should work together for the common good. Nearly everyone would like to see things improve, however few people actually like change in order to get there, and they definitely don't want change unless it means their stature or team grows. 
 It's common to find a passive-aggressive streak, cloaked under supposed Midwest Niceness, which enables bad behavior by individuals such as saying they agree in public then sabotaging afterwards. A lot of situations where if people don't like something they find a way to drag it out through delays, rescheduled meetings, etc. etc. etc. that they hope it will just fade away, and unfortunately much of the time they are 'rewarded' and it does just fade away. Definite cliques based on geography, such as it's all about Des Moines, Iowa. This means that current employees who are not in a core location can no longer apply for jobs, even if they have been full time remote for years (they are not grandfathered in), and likely they will slowly be laid off over time (if they don't self-select out first, which saves the company money). This is going to result in a painful multi-year shift of strong talent out the door being replaced by mediocre talent in core locations, and less diversity in the non-branch workforce overall. Low pay for the industry, high turnover in the call centers, and limited opportunities to advance. 

I spent 5 years or so of my life moving up the ladder only to find out that, according to a job listing I saw, a BRAND NEW Customer Success Specialist, the role that I started out in when I first started working with Wells, would be making within pennies of what I made hourly.

I took a moment to reflect upon this and figured out I seemingly hadn't moved up in a way that mattered after all those years. I also hadn't gotten a raise of any kind during my last couple of years w/ Wells. This is coming from someone who was constantly praised as a tOp PeRfOrMeR.

My experience is that most call center bankers wind up quitting because of burnout associated with the stress of dealing with angry customers 8+ hours a day or because they found something better externally. You know that thing they tell college freshman where you look to the left and to the right and the professor tells you that only one of the three of you will graduate? They should say something similar to new call center employees because a few months after starting a new role you may notice that a bunch of your coworkers have left and (hopefully) been replaced.

I absolutely wouldn't call those who stick around "misguided," but it can be extremely difficult to escape the phones. It's obviously possible, but I couldn't do it in 5 years! When you get asked during a job interview where you see yourself 5 years from now, do you respond with "I see myself taking much harder phone calls for marginally better pay"? I would hope not. That's more time than it would have taken me to go back to school and get a completely different bachelor's degree. 

There were also people in a previous department that I worked in ~3.5 years ago that constantly complained about the job and were desperate to find ANYTHING off of the phones internally who were still there, doing the same thing, as of my last day. I hope they find something better.

I waited and waited and finally at around 6 PM, I got 2 emails : One for virtual on-boarding and another for virtual induction.

Virtual on-boarding email contained my employee ID and a few forms. The forms need to be filled-in, printed, signed, scanned and sent back to them over email by Sunday EOD. I attended the virtual induction over a Zoom call on my joining day. I hoped to get my manager contact details on the same day, but we were told to contact the HR for this information. HR did not share any contact details, instead asked me to wait for my manager to contact me. After 4 days, on Friday my manager called me and confirmed that she is going raise an asset allocation request on my behalf. Next week, she again called me and asked me to collect my work laptop from the Raidurgam office. Overall a good experience, but it gave me a great deal of anxiety. It would have been better to know all of these details about the joining process in advance as in what will happen next and when. That's the reason I am sharing it here to help any fellow team members.
